texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Stimulus I- Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2020
texts.text: Stimulus I- Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2020

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Coronavirus Preparedeness and Response Supplemental Appropriations act is summarized  here by the House Appropriations Committee.  Key highlights
texts.text: The Coronavirus Preparedeness and Response Supplemental Appropriations act is summarized  here by the House Appropriations Committee.  Key highlights

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Small Business Administration, Disaster Loans Program Account
texts.text: Small Business Administration, Disaster Loans Program Account

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Act provides appropriations to the Small Business Administration for the Disaster Loans Program Account.The SBA's Economic Injury Disaster Loan program provides small businesses with working capital loans of up to $2 million that can provide vital economic support to small businesses to help overcome the temporary loss of revenue they are experiencing.Resources pertaining to the Coronavirus can be found here. Small businesses can apply for relief online.
texts.text: The Act provides appropriations to the Small Business Administration for the Disaster Loans Program Account.The SBA's Economic Injury Disaster Loan program provides small businesses with working capital loans of up to $2 million that can provide vital economic support to small businesses to help overcome the temporary loss of revenue they are experiencing.Resources pertaining to the Coronavirus can be found here. Small businesses can apply for relief online.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Medicare Beneficiaries Expanded Telehealth Benefits During COVID-19 Outbreak
texts.text: Medicare Beneficiaries Expanded Telehealth Benefits During COVID-19 Outbreak

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Under the Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act and Section 1135 waiver authority, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) broadened access to Medicare telehealth services, so beneficiaries can get a wider range of services from their doctors and other clinicians without traveling to a health care facility.
texts.text: Under the Coronavirus Preparedness and Response Supplemental Appropriations Act and Section 1135 waiver authority, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) broadened access to Medicare telehealth services, so beneficiaries can get a wider range of services from their doctors and other clinicians without traveling to a health care facility.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Under this Section 1135 waiver expansion, a range of providers, such as doctors, nurse practitioners, clinical psychologists, and licensed clinical social workers, can offer a specific set of telehealth services. The specific set of services beneficiaries can get include evaluation and management visits (common office visits), mental health counseling, and preventive health screenings. Beneficiaries can get telehealth services in any health care facility including a physician's office, hospital, nursing home or rural health clinic, as well as from their homes. Please see the Fact Sheet and FAQ for more details.
texts.text: Under this Section 1135 waiver expansion, a range of providers, such as doctors, nurse practitioners, clinical psychologists, and licensed clinical social workers, can offer a specific set of telehealth services. The specific set of services beneficiaries can get include evaluation and management visits (common office visits), mental health counseling, and preventive health screenings. Beneficiaries can get telehealth services in any health care facility including a physician's office, hospital, nursing home or rural health clinic, as well as from their homes. Please see the Fact Sheet and FAQ for more details.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Stimulus II - Families First Act (H.R. 6201)
texts.text: Stimulus II - Families First Act (H.R. 6201)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Families First Coronavirus Response Act, the bill is summarized below in detail and here by the House Appropriations Committee. Here are a few highlights
texts.text: The Families First Coronavirus Response Act, the bill is summarized below in detail and here by the House Appropriations Committee. Here are a few highlights

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Food Security Provisions
texts.text: Food Security Provisions

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The bill includes several provisions to enhance food security during the epidemic.
texts.text: The bill includes several provisions to enhance food security during the epidemic.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: · Child Nutrition
texts.text: Child Nutrition

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Provides USDA Secretary authority to issue nationwide school meals waivers, eliminating paperwork for states and help schools adopt and implement more quickly
texts.text: o Provides USDA Secretary authority to issue nationwide school meals waivers, eliminating paperwork for states and help schools adopt and implement more quickly

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Allows all child and adult care centers to operate as non-congregate
texts.text: o Allows all child and adult care centers to operate as non-congregate

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Waives all meal pattern requirements if there is a disruption to the food supply
texts.text: o Waives all meal pattern requirements if there is a disruption to the food supply

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Allows states to use SNAP money to give extra to families to school age children who qualify for free or reduced-priced meals (benefits equal to the value of school meals)
texts.text: o Allows states to use SNAP money to give extra to families to school age children who qualify for free or reduced-priced meals (benefits equal to the value of school meals)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o $500 million extra for WIC
texts.text: o $500 million extra for WIC

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Allows WIC to certify participants without being physically present at WIC clinics
texts.text: o Allows WIC to certify participants without being physically present at WIC clinics

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Waives stocking requirements for WIC
texts.text: o Waives stocking requirements for WIC

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: · SNAP
texts.text: · SNAP

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Suspends work and work training requirements
texts.text: o Suspends work and work training requirements

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Allows states to request waivers to provide emergency benefits to existing SNAP beneficiaries up to the maximum monthly allotment
texts.text: o Allows states to request waivers to provide emergency benefits to existing SNAP beneficiaries up to the maximum monthly allotment

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Gives Secretary discretion to give states more flexibility in managing SNAP caseloads
texts.text: o Gives Secretary discretion to give states more flexibility in managing SNAP caseloads

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Requires state waiver requests and USDA response to be publicly available online
texts.text: o Requires state waiver requests and USDA response to be publicly available online

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: · Miscellaneous
texts.text: · Miscellaneous

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Provides $400 million for TEFAP ($300 for food/$100 for storage)
texts.text: o Provides $400 million for TEFAP ($300 for food/$100 for storage)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Provides $100 million food security assistance for territories
texts.text: o Provides $100 million food security assistance for territories

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: o Provides $250 million Senior Nutrition program in the Administration for Community Living (ACL)
texts.text: o Provides $250 million Senior Nutrition program in the Administration for Community Living (ACL)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Employer Provided Paid Sick Leave
texts.text: Employer Provided Paid Sick Leave

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The benefit would be provided to employees of private businesses with fewer than 500 employees and employees of public entities for the purpose of illness or quarantine related to COVID-19, or for the care of someone who is quarantined or ill because of COVID-19. Employers may exempt health care providers or emergency responders from this benefit. Full-time employees can receive up to 80 hours, with part-time employees receiving up to the number of hours they would normally work over a 2-week period. It's important to note the paid sick leave benefit would only be in effect through the end of 2020. Limits exist on daily and aggregate paid sick leave amounts provided to employees.
texts.text: The benefit would be provided to employees of private businesses with fewer than 500 employees and employees of public entities for the purpose of illness or quarantine related to COVID-19, or for the care of someone who is quarantined or ill because of COVID-19. Employers may exempt health care providers or emergency responders from this benefit. Full-time employees can receive up to 80 hours, with part-time employees receiving up to the number of hours they would normally work over a 2-week period. It's important to note the paid sick leave benefit would only be in effect through the end of 2020. Limits exist on daily and aggregate paid sick leave amounts provided to employees.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Also worth noting that the U.S. Secretary of Labor would be empowered to grant hardship exemptions for certain businesses with fewer than 50 employees, and to exclude certain health care providers and emergency responders from the benefit.
texts.text: Also worth noting that the U.S. Secretary of Labor would be empowered to grant hardship exemptions for certain businesses with fewer than 50 employees, and to exclude certain health care providers and emergency responders from the benefit.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Employers will be reimbursed through a payroll tax credit, which applies to for-profit and nonprofit employers equal to 100% of the qualified sick leave wages paid.
texts.text: Employers will be reimbursed through a payroll tax credit, which applies to for-profit and nonprofit employers equal to 100% of the qualified sick leave wages paid.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Expansion of the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)
texts.text: Expansion of the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The bill extends paid leave -connected to a public health emergency related to COVID-19 -to employees at organizations with fewer than 500 total employees to care for a child if childcare is unavailable. Employees would have to be employed for at least 30 days by their employer.
texts.text: The bill extends paid leave -connected to a public health emergency related to COVID-19 -to employees at organizations with fewer than 500 total employees to care for a child if childcare is unavailable. Employees would have to be employed for at least 30 days by their employer.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: As with paid sick leave, the U.S. Secretary of Labor would be empowered to grant hardship exemptions for certain businesses with fewer than 50 employees and to exclude certain health care providers and emergency responders.
texts.text: As with paid sick leave, the U.S. Secretary of Labor would be empowered to grant hardship exemptions for certain businesses with fewer than 50 employees and to exclude certain health care providers and emergency responders.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Employers will be reimbursed through a payroll tax credit, which applies to for-profit and nonprofit employers equal to 100% of the qualified family leave wages paid.
texts.text: Employers will be reimbursed through a payroll tax credit, which applies to for-profit and nonprofit employers equal to 100% of the qualified family leave wages paid.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Emergency Unemployment Insurance Stabilization for States
texts.text: Emergency Unemployment Insurance Stabilization for States

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The bill provides federal support to states to underwrite unemployment benefits in states where unemployment enrollment spikes. Specifically, it includes $1 billion in 2020 for emergency grants to states for activities related to processing and paying unemployment insurance (UI) benefits, under certain conditions. States become eligible for the emergency grants when the number of unemployment compensation claims has increase by at least 10 percent over the same quarter in the previous calendar year
texts.text: The bill provides federal support to states to underwrite unemployment benefits in states where unemployment enrollment spikes. Specifically, it includes $1 billion in 2020 for emergency grants to states for activities related to processing and paying unemployment insurance (UI) benefits, under certain conditions. States become eligible for the emergency grants when the number of unemployment compensation claims has increase by at least 10 percent over the same quarter in the previous calendar year

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Coronavirus Testing
texts.text: Coronavirus Testing

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The bill requires all health insurers to make testing (not treatment) free. Specifically, the bill:
texts.text: The bill requires all health insurers to make testing (not treatment) free. Specifically, the bill:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: · Requires CMS to designate a modifier code to identify claims where cost sharing should not be charged to the patient.
texts.text: Requires CMS to designate a modifier code to identify claims where cost sharing should not be charged to the patient.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: · Provides $1 billion to the National Disaster Medical System to reimburse providers for the costs of testing for uninsured individuals.
texts.text: Provides $1 billion to the National Disaster Medical System to reimburse providers for the costs of testing for uninsured individuals.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Temporary Increase of Medicaid FMAP
texts.text: Temporary Increase of Medicaid FMAP

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The bill provides increased federal support for Medicaid spending to ease financial strain on state budgets during the pandemic in the form of a 6.2% emergency FMAP increase to states.
texts.text: The bill provides increased federal support for Medicaid spending to ease financial strain on state budgets during the pandemic in the form of a 6.2% emergency FMAP increase to states.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Nutrition, SNAP, WIC, and USDA
texts.text: Nutrition, SNAP, WIC, and USDA

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The USDA's Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) launched a new webpage www.fns.usda.gov/coronavirus -to provide key information on COVID-19 nutrition assistance for program operators and the public.
texts.text: The USDA's Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) launched a new webpage www.fns.usda.gov/coronavirus -to provide key information on COVID-19 nutrition assistance for program operators and the public.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Edu cation and Labor Committee has developed an extremely helpful FAQ's of the Families First Corona Virus Response Act's child nutrition provisionsavailable here!
texts.text: Edu cation and Labor Committee has developed an extremely helpful FAQ's of the Families First Corona Virus Response Act's child nutrition provisionsavailable here!

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has created a helpful waiver tracking page. If you click on a state, you can see what waivers the state has requested for child nutrition programs (school meals/summer), SNAP, WIC, and USDA foods, as well as USDA's response to the waiver.
texts.text: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has created a helpful waiver tracking page. If you click on a state, you can see what waivers the state has requested for child nutrition programs (school meals/summer), SNAP, WIC, and USDA foods, as well as USDA's response to the waiver.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: USDA posted guidance on Pandemic EBT; meal delivery; and nationwide waivers on meal times, after school activities and non-congregate feeding. They also posted SNAP guidance on time limits and emergency allotments. https://www.fns.usda.gov/disaster/pandemic/covid-19.
texts.text: USDA posted guidance on Pandemic EBT; meal delivery; and nationwide waivers on meal times, after school activities and non-congregate feeding. They also posted SNAP guidance on time limits and emergency allotments. https://www.fns.usda.gov/disaster/pandemic/covid-19.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Medicaid & Health Benefits
texts.text: Medicaid & Health Benefits

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) announced it is granting exceptions from reporting requirements and extensions for clinicians and providers participating in Medicare quality reporting programs with respect to upcoming measure reporting and data submission for those programs.
texts.text: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) announced it is granting exceptions from reporting requirements and extensions for clinicians and providers participating in Medicare quality reporting programs with respect to upcoming measure reporting and data submission for those programs.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: CMS released guidance regarding the increased FMAP available to states as part of the Families First Coronavirus Response Act. As a reminder, Section 6008 of the act provides a temporary 6.2 percentage point increase to each qualifying state and territory's Federal Medical Assistance Percentage (FMAP). One noteworthy item is that for states to qualify for the FMAP increase, states cannot end coverage for anyone who is eligible as of March 18   or those who become eligible after that date until end of public health emergency, unless the individual voluntarily terminates enrollment or is no longer a resident of the state.
texts.text: CMS released guidance regarding the increased FMAP available to states as part of the Families First Coronavirus Response Act. As a reminder, Section 6008 of the act provides a temporary 6.2 percentage point increase to each qualifying state and territory's Federal Medical Assistance Percentage (FMAP). One noteworthy item is that for states to qualify for the FMAP increase, states cannot end coverage for anyone who is eligible as of March 18   or those who become eligible after that date until end of public health emergency, unless the individual voluntarily terminates enrollment or is no longer a resident of the state.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: CMS released four Medicaid waiver templates designed to help state Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance Programs (CHIP) during the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak. The Medicaid waiver templates are intended to make application processes faster and decrease administrative burden as states struggle to contain the coronavirus. The materials released include checklists for the 1115 Medicaid Demonstration waiver, the 1135 waiver, a template for the 1915(c) Appendix K regarding home and community-based services, and the Medicaid Disaster State Plan Amendment.
texts.text: CMS released four Medicaid waiver templates designed to help state Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance Programs (CHIP) during the 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak. The Medicaid waiver templates are intended to make application processes faster and decrease administrative burden as states struggle to contain the coronavirus. The materials released include checklists for the 1115 Medicaid Demonstration waiver, the 1135 waiver, a template for the 1915(c) Appendix K regarding home and community-based services, and the Medicaid Disaster State Plan Amendment.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: *** Alabama Approved CMS approved Medicaid section 1135 waivers for 7 additional states in response to COVID-19. This brings the total number of approved Section 1135 waivers for states to 23. The waivers were approved within days of states' submitting them, and offer states new flexibilities to focus their resources on combatting the outbreak and providing the best possible care to Medicaid beneficiaries in their states.
texts.text: *** Alabama Approved CMS approved Medicaid section 1135 waivers for 7 additional states in response to COVID-19. This brings the total number of approved Section 1135 waivers for states to 23. The waivers were approved within days of states' submitting them, and offer states new flexibilities to focus their resources on combatting the outbreak and providing the best possible care to Medicaid beneficiaries in their states.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: CMS has withdrawn its proposed rule to crackdown on state Medicaid eligibility determinations from the Office of Management and Budget's regulatory review process. 'This proposed rule would have strengthened the integrity of the Medicaid eligibility determination process including verification, changes in circumstance, and redetermination," the agency said in its description of the rule. The proposed rule was supposed to be published in April. Healthcare experts and advocates have worried that tightening eligibility rules would make it tougher for eligible people to enroll in the program and maintain coverage, even if it reduced improper Medicaid enrollment and federal payments to states.
texts.text: CMS has withdrawn its proposed rule to crackdown on state Medicaid eligibility determinations from the Office of Management and Budget's regulatory review process. 'This proposed rule would have strengthened the integrity of the Medicaid eligibility determination process including verification, changes in circumstance, and redetermination," the agency said in its description of the rule. The proposed rule was supposed to be published in April. Healthcare experts and advocates have worried that tightening eligibility rules would make it tougher for eligible people to enroll in the program and maintain coverage, even if it reduced improper Medicaid enrollment and federal payments to states.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: CMS issued Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) to clarify coverage for the diagnosis and treatment of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) by catastrophic health plans. A catastrophic health plan generally may not provide coverage of an essential health benefit before an enrollee meets the plan's deductible. Through this FAQ, CMS is announcing that the agency will not take enforcement action against any health issuer that amends its catastrophic plans to provide coverage without imposing cost-sharing requirements for COVID-19 related services before an enrollee meets the catastrophic plan's deductible.
texts.text: CMS issued Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) to clarify coverage for the diagnosis and treatment of the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) by catastrophic health plans. A catastrophic health plan generally may not provide coverage of an essential health benefit before an enrollee meets the plan's deductible. Through this FAQ, CMS is announcing that the agency will not take enforcement action against any health issuer that amends its catastrophic plans to provide coverage without imposing cost-sharing requirements for COVID-19 related services before an enrollee meets the catastrophic plan's deductible.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: On Tuesday, March 24, CMS posted guidance on Payment and Grace Period Flexibilities for Issuers Offering Coverage on the Federally-facilitated Exchanges and State-based Exchanges on the Federal Platform. Under the newly released guidance, CMS announced that it will exercise enforcement discretion to permit issuers of qualified health plans (QHPs) and stand-alone dental plans (SADPs) to extend payment deadlines for initial binder payments, as well as ongoing premium payments during the period of the COVID-19 national emergency
texts.text: On Tuesday, March 24, CMS posted guidance on Payment and Grace Period Flexibilities for Issuers Offering Coverage on the Federally-facilitated Exchanges and State-based Exchanges on the Federal Platform. Under the newly released guidance, CMS announced that it will exercise enforcement discretion to permit issuers of qualified health plans (QHPs) and stand-alone dental plans (SADPs) to extend payment deadlines for initial binder payments, as well as ongoing premium payments during the period of the COVID-19 national emergency

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Federal Taxes
texts.text: Federal Taxes

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced that the IRS will move the Federal income tax filing deadline ahead to July 15, three months after the normal deadline for Americans to send in their returns. All taxpayers and businesses will have this additional time to file and make payments without interest or penalties. Corporate taxpayers may delay up to $10 million in federal income tax payments. All other taxpayers (regardless of filing status) with a federal income tax liability may delay up to $1 million in federal income tax payments. Interest, penalties and additions to tax with respect to such postponed federal income tax payments will not begin to accrue until July 16, 2020. No extension was provided for the filing of any returns or the payment or deposit of any other type of federal tax.
texts.text: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced that the IRS will move the Federal income tax filing deadline ahead to July 15, three months after the normal deadline for Americans to send in their returns. All taxpayers and businesses will have this additional time to file and make payments without interest or penalties. Corporate taxpayers may delay up to $10 million in federal income tax payments. All other taxpayers (regardless of filing status) with a federal income tax liability may delay up to $1 million in federal income tax payments. Interest, penalties and additions to tax with respect to such postponed federal income tax payments will not begin to accrue until July 16, 2020. No extension was provided for the filing of any returns or the payment or deposit of any other type of federal tax.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Federal Housing Agency
texts.text: Federal Housing Agency

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) announced that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (collectively known as Government-Sponsored Enterprises) will offer multifamily property owners mortgage forbearance with the condition that they suspend all evictions for renters unable to pay rent due to the impact of coronavirus pandemic.
texts.text: The Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) announced that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (collectively known as Government-Sponsored Enterprises) will offer multifamily property owners mortgage forbearance with the condition that they suspend all evictions for renters unable to pay rent due to the impact of coronavirus pandemic.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Department of Housing and Urban Development will provide immediate relief to renters and homeowners by suspending foreclosures and evictions for mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration until the end of April. This move will affect about 8.1 million mortgages.
texts.text: The Department of Housing and Urban Development will provide immediate relief to renters and homeowners by suspending foreclosures and evictions for mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration until the end of April. This move will affect about 8.1 million mortgages.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Department of Labor
texts.text: Department of Labor

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Department of Labor released guidance today explaining the paid sick leave and expanded family medical leave under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (aka, 'Stimulus II').
texts.text: The Department of Labor released guidance today explaining the paid sick leave and expanded family medical leave under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act (aka, 'Stimulus II').

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Veterans Affairs
texts.text: Veterans Affairs

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is preparing to support the civilian healthcare system if the public health emergency worsens. The VA is authorized to assist during major emergency situations and has procedures in place to do so.
texts.text: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is preparing to support the civilian healthcare system if the public health emergency worsens. The VA is authorized to assist during major emergency situations and has procedures in place to do so.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Health and Medical Equipment
texts.text: Health and Medical Equipment

texts.label: text
texts.orig: President Trump announced that he will invoke the Defense Production Act to mobilize the private sector to manufacture goods needed to fight the coronavirus pandemic. The Defense Production Act will allow the administration to force American industry to manufacture medical supplies that are in short supply in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic. Hospitals, health workers and state and local officials have said they are running out of personal protective equipment (PPE), such as masks, gowns and gloves, that are crucial to keeping doctors and nurses safe while treating patients.
texts.text: President Trump announced that he will invoke the Defense Production Act to mobilize the private sector to manufacture goods needed to fight the coronavirus pandemic. The Defense Production Act will allow the administration to force American industry to manufacture medical supplies that are in short supply in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic. Hospitals, health workers and state and local officials have said they are running out of personal protective equipment (PPE), such as masks, gowns and gloves, that are crucial to keeping doctors and nurses safe while treating patients.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: The president also issued an Executive Order on Prioritizing and Allocating Health and Medical Resources to Respond to the Spread of Covid-19 . The executive order gives the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) the authority to determine the allocation of all health and medical resources, including controlling the distribution of such materials (including applicable services) in the civilian market, for responding to the COVID-19 outbreak.
texts.text: The president also issued an Executive Order on Prioritizing and Allocating Health and Medical Resources to Respond to the Spread of Covid-19 . The executive order gives the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) the authority to determine the allocation of all health and medical resources, including controlling the distribution of such materials (including applicable services) in the civilian market, for responding to the COVID-19 outbreak.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Some states reopen ACA enrollment- In a move to ensure Americans receive affordable health care during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, some states are establishing special enrollment periods, allowing people to purchase health insurance under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) at healthcare.gov . The ACA's regular enrollment period ended in December, but the District of Columbia and several states with their own health insurance exchanges have reopened enrollment, including California, Colorado, Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Nevada, New York, Rhode Island, Vermont and Washington.
texts.text: Some states reopen ACA enrollment- In a move to ensure Americans receive affordable health care during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, some states are establishing special enrollment periods, allowing people to purchase health insurance under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) at healthcare.gov . The ACA's regular enrollment period ended in December, but the District of Columbia and several states with their own health insurance exchanges have reopened enrollment, including California, Colorado, Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Nevada, New York, Rhode Island, Vermont and Washington.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Ventilators - The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is trying to quickly increase the number of ventilators available to treat COVID-19 patients and issued guidance that allows manufacturers to modify devices into ventilators. They also issued guidance on how certain ventilator products can be modified to support two patients at once.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Converting Hotels to Hospitals- The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers issued a draft request for proposals for contracts that can convert hotels, convention centers and other large spaces, into temporary healthcare facilities should a need arise.
texts.text: Converting Hotels to Hospitals- The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers issued a draft request for proposals for contracts that can convert hotels, convention centers and other large spaces, into temporary healthcare facilities should a need arise.
